author: Legal Correspondent
text:
The Supreme Court on Friday asked the Centre to consider appointing a nodal officer in the Ministry of External Affairs to coordinate efforts for release of Indian hostages abducted by terror outfit Islamic State (IS) in Iraq.

40 Indians missing

A Bench comprising Chief Justice of India T.S. Thakur and Justices M.Y. Eqbal and R. Banumathi suggested the measure on a public interest litigation (PIL) petition filed by advocate Gaurav K. Bansal, who quoted an RTI reply from the Indian Embassy in Baghdad that about 40 Indians are still missing in war-ravaged Iraq since 2014.

The court did not issue any notice and disposed of the petition.

Besides various reliefs, the plea had sought a direction to the Centre to “forthwith intervene and expedite the process of release” of Indians held hostages in Iraq.
title: Court for appointment of official for hostage release
